Martin Savage   Department of Physics, University of Washington, Seattle    Effective Field Theory in Nuclear Physics      I will discuss the application of effective field theory to nuclear physics. This will include recent work on constructing a partially-quenched effective field theory to enable the chiral extrapolation of future lattice calculations.

Summer School on Neutron Scattering       Renate Bercher        bercher at cvax.psi.ch               Fri Apr 21 22:39:35 CDT 1995                 Previous message:  Request for comments  Re: Area Detectors            Next message:  9th International Conference on Liquid and Amorphous Metals               Messages sorted by:                  [ date ]                 [ thread ]                 [ subject ]                 [ author ]                                 --------------------------------------------------------------------------                       Third Summer School on Neutron Scattering                            Magnetic Neutron Scattering             20 - 26 August 1995, Lyceum Alpinum, Zuoz, Switzerland    The main purpose of the Summer School is to give participants an introduction to the basic principles of neutron scattering and its application to the study of magnetic materials. The lectures will cover both theoretical and experi- mental aspects, with particular emphasis on the future utilisation of the instrumentation now under construction at the spallation neutron source SINQ at PSI. No previous knowledge of the subject is required, but an honours degree in natural science (equivalent to the diploma) is essential. The programme of the School will include seminars and poster sessions in which the participants can present their own results in the field of neutron scattering from magnetic materials.  Invited Lecturers:              Topics:  P. Boeni, P. Fischer,           Introduction to neutron scattering A. Furrer, ETHZ & PSI           (general, magnetic, polarized neutrons)  G. Bauer, Villigen              The spallation neutron source SINQ  W. Buehrer, PSI; B. Dorner      Survey of instruments for neutron scattering ILL; S.W. Lovesey, ISIS         at SINQ, ILL and ISIS  G. Aeppli, Murray Hill          Neutron scattering in heavy fermion systems P.A. Alekseev, Moscow           INS in Kondo and intermediate valence systems E. Bauer, Wien                  Neutron scattering in Kondo systems R.A. Cowley, Oxford             Critical magnetic neutron scattering R. Gaehler, Muenchen            Zero-field neutron spin-echo techniques H.U. Guedel, Bern               INS from metallic centers in polynuclear                                 molecular complexes M. Hennion, Saclay              Spin excitations in spin glasses G.H. Lander, Karlsruhe          Magnetic scattering by neutrons and x-rays B. Lebech, Risoe                Magnetic structure determination by neutron                                 diffraction S.W. Lovesey, Didcot            Magnetic moment formation (localized vs.                                 itinerant behaviour) M. Loewenhaupt, Juelich         Magnetic excitations (spin waves in hard                                 magnets) C.F. Majkrzak, Gaithersburg     Neutron scattering studies of magnetic rare                                 earth multilayers J. Mesot, Villigen              Crystal-field excitations in high-temperature                                 superconductors G. Badurek, Wien                Polarized neutron optics L.P. Regnault, Grenoble         Spin fluctuations in high-temperature                                 superconductors M.T. Rekveldt, Delft            Neutron depolarization in magnetic materials A. Schenck, Villigen            Muon spin rotation in magnetic materials J. Schweizer, Grenoble          Neutron scattering in one-dimensional                                 magnetic compounds;                                 Neutron diffraction studies of nuclear                                 magnetic ordering W. Wagner, Villigen             Neutron scattering in nanocrystalline                                 magnetic materials    Organization of the School: W.E. Fischer (Chairman), R. Bercher (Secretary)                             Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen  Program Committee: P. Boeni, P. Fischer, A. Furrer (Chairman)                    Laboratory for Neutron Scattering, ETH Zuerich & PSI Villigen  Residential accomodation will be available at the Lyceum Alpinum in Zuoz (costs: approximately 500 Swiss Francs, including full board, excursion, banquet and Proceedings). The number of participants will be limited to 100. The language of the School is English. Closing date for applying is                                 30. June 1995.  For further information and application forms, write to  Mrs. Renate Bercher Paul Scherrer Institut CH-5232 Villigen PSI Switzerland Tel.  +41 56 99 3402 Fax   +41 56 99 3131 Email:  Renate.Bercher at PSI.CH    --------------------------------------------------------------------------------                                Previous message:  Request for comments  Re: Area Detectors     Next message:  9th International Conference on Liquid and Amorphous Metals               Messages sorted by:                  [ date ]                 [ thread ]                 [ subject ]                 [ author ]                          More information about the Neutron mailing list

John F. Krizmanic, Ph.D.       Associate Research Scientist   Universities Space Research Association (USRA)   High Energy Cosmic Ray Group   Gamma Ray and Cosmic Ray Astrophysics Branch   Laboratory for High Energy Astrophysics   NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center     Visiting Associate Research Scientist   Department of Physics and Astronomy   The Johns Hopkins University               Areas of Research      Astroparticle physics.  Current research includes measuring atmospheric cosmic ray induced muon and meson production and the antimatter and light isotope components of cosmic rays using balloon-borne experiments.  Investigating the interactions of ultrahigh energy (E > 10^20 eV) particles in the atmosphere of the earth.  Also involved in the research and development of novel detectors (particularly semiconductor) and related VLSI electronics for gamma ray astronomy and charged particle spectroscopy. Dr. Robert E. Streitmatter     DATE OF BIRTH:        August 13, 1941      PRESENT POSITION:        Astrophysicist,  Laboratory for High Energy Astrophysics, Goddard Space Flight Center, Group Leader, High Energy Cosmic Radiation      RESEARCH AREA:        Particle Astrophysics;  composition  measurements of cosmic radiation - antimatter,  isotopes, and elements; instruments for cosmic ray detection; analysis of data;  theoretical modeling of cosmic ray phenomena and propagation.      EDUCATION:            1973  - Ph.D. University of Chicago - Physics    1963  - B.S Northwestern University - Engineering Physics          PREVIOUS POSITIONS:      1979 - 1980 NAS/NRC Research Associate, Goddard Space Flight Center   1972 - 1979 Post-doctoral Research Associate, University of Maryland  1964 - 1972 Research Assistant, University of Chicago  1963 - 1964 Engineer, University of Chicago, Physics Dept.      PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR:     High Energy Cosmic Ray Balloon Investigations:     High Energy Gas Cherenkov Spectrometer (HEGCS)  Large Isotopic Composition Experiment (ALICE)  Medium Energy Antiproton Experiment (MEAP)  Low Energy Antiproton Experiment (LEAP)  Isotope Matter Antimatter  Experiment (IMAX)  Isotope Magnet Experiment (ISOMAX)      CO-INVESTIGATOR:     Spacelab Transition Radiation Ionization Calorimeter (TRIC) Experiment,   Energy Spectra of Cosmic Ray Electrons, Protons, and Heavier Nuclei:  1978 - 1983  Medium Energy Antiproton Experiment (MEAP)  Matter Antimatter Superconducting Spectrometer (MASS)  WiZard, Astromag Experiment   Isotope Spectrometer for Astromag (LISA)  Positron Electron Magnet Spectrometer: 1989, 1993 - 1994      COMMITTEES:       1990 - 1993    Cosmic and Heliospheric Management Working Group (CHMOWG)   1989 - 1992 NASA Balloon Working Group  Station Committee   1989        NASA Balloon Magnet Facility Users Group   1985 - 1988 Astromag Facility Definition Team   1985        Space and Earth Sciences Directorate Space   1984 - 1992 Goddard Library Council              PROFESSIONAL SOCIETY  MEMBERSHIPS:     American Physical Society  American Association for the Advancement of Science   Tau Beta Pi--Past president, Northwestern University Chapter   Sigma Xi       REFEREED PUBLICATIONS :    Advance to  Other Significant Publications      Bob Streitmatter Refereed Publications        1996 "Antimatter in the Universe", R.E. Dr. Eric Richard Christian    DATE OF BIRTH:   November 25, 1960    PRESENT POSITION:               1989 - Present -- Research Scientist,   Universities Space Research Association ,   NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center , High Energy Cosmic Ray Group (Code 661).          RESEARCH AREA:              Cosmic ray isotopic composition and the antiproton spectrum as a probe of nucleosynthesis and propagation. Also anomalous cosmic rays and solar modulation, including the charge-sign asymmetry problem.          EDUCATION:           1989 -- Ph.D., Physics, California Institute of Technology          1985 -- MS., Physics, California Institute of Technology          1982 -- BA., Physics (Honors), Astronomy, University of Pennsylvania        PREVIOUS POSITIONS:               1982-1989 -- Graduate Research Assistant, Caltech.         1982 -- Instructor, U. of Pennsylvania.         1982 -- Teaching Assistant, U. of Pennsylvania.         1979-1982 -- Computer Consultant, U. of Pennsylvania.         1978-1982 -- Undergraduate Research Assistant, U. of Pennsylvania.              AWARDS:              1995 -- Excellence in Scientific Research Award,             Universities Space Research Association          SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATIONS:           1992 - Present --   Advanced Composition Explorer (ACE) , Assistant to the Project Scientist       Explorer class spacecraft with August 1997 launch date.           Cosmic Ray Isotope Spectrometer (CRIS)  on ACE, Science Team member.           Solar Isotope Spectrometer (SIS)  on ACE, Science Team member.         1992 - Present -- ISOtope MAgnet eXperiment (ISOMAX), Co-I       Balloon-borne cosmic ray spectrometer which will study the 10Be radioactive clock.         1990 - Present --   Isotope Matter-Antimatter eXperiment (IMAX) , Co-I       Balloon-borne cosmic ray spectrometer which studied antiprotons, and hydrogen and helium isotopes.         1987 - Present -- Cosmic Ray Subsystems (CRS) on the Voyager 1 and 2 deep space probes       Data analysis and investigation of anomalous cosmic rays.         1993 - Present -- Trans-Iron Galactic Element Recorder (TIGER), Goddard Instrument Manager       Balloon-borne ultra-heavy-element spectrometer.         1991 - Present -- POsitron-Electron Magnet Spectrometer (POEMS), Co-I       Currently in Step 2 MIDEX proposal stage.         1989 - 1995 -- A Large Isotopic Composition Experiment (ALICE), Goddard Instrument Manager       Balloon-borne spectrometer which studied galactic cosmic ray isotopes from silicon through iron.         1989 - 1991 -- Astromag, Assistant to the Project Scientist       Space Station Attached Payload for galactic cosmic rays.         1982 - 1987 -- High Energy Isotopic Spectrometer Telescope (HEIST)       Balloon-borne galactic cosmic ray isotope spectrometer.              COMMUNITY SERVICE:             1996 -- Mentor for NASA Cooperative Satellite Learning Program, Old Bridge High School, NJ            1993 - Present -- Volunteer Naturalist, Merkle Wildlife Refuge            1991 - Present -- Judge for Prince George's County Science Fair            1992 -- Gave "Introducing Goddard" talk on Advanced Composition Explorer at visitor's center          PROFESSIONAL SOCIETY MEMBERSHIPS:               American Physical Society              American Geophysical Union         INVITED AND SOLICITED LECTURES             "Anomalous Cosmic Ray Hydrogen", COSPAR, Birmingham, England, 1996.            "The Return and Implications of Anomalous Cosmic Ray Hydrogen", AGU Spring Meeting, Baltimore, 1995. Eric Wu and Anthony Bolmarcich and Marc Snir and                  David Wootton and Farid Parpia and Anthony Chan and                  Ewing L. Lusk and  William Gropp ",      title   =          "From Trace Generation to Visualization: {A}                  Performance Framework for Distributed Parallel                  Systems.",      crossref   =       "SC00-CD-ROM",      abstract   =   {In this paper we describe a trace analysis framework, from trace                   generation to                    visualization. It includes a unified tracing facility on IBM                   SP systems, a self-defining interval file format, an API for                   framework extensions, utilities for merging and statistics                   generation, and a visualization tool with preview and                   multiple time-space diagrams. The trace environment is                   extremely scalable, and combines MPI events with system                   activities in the same set of trace files, one for each SMP                   node. Since the amount of trace data may be very large,                   utilities are developed to convert and merge individual                   trace files into a self-defining interval trace file with                   multiple frame directories. The interval format allows the                   development of multiple time-space diagrams, such as                   thread-activity view, processor-activity view, etc., from                   the same interval file. A visualization tool, Jumpshot, is                   modified to visualize these views. A statistics utility is                   developed using the API, along with its graphics viewer.},      area   =   "PV",      areaseq   =   "0",   }      @ InProceedings { vin01:mpi-impl ,      author   =     {Rajkumar Vinkat and Philip M. [BANANA] message from Persi Diaconis...           Teresa Gaman             tagaman@stat.stanford.edu               Wed Sep 27 16:49:38 2000                  Previous message:  [BANANA] SCCM Seminar, Monday 9/25             Next message:  [BANANA] Two SCCM seminars next week               Messages sorted by:                  [ date ]                 [ thread ]                 [ subject ]                 [ author ]                                 Monte Carlo Markov Chains in Scientific Computing.  Applied workers in chemistry, biology, physics, statistics and computer science have invented novel algorithms (simulated tempering, hybrid algorithms, umbrella sampling, particle sampling and many others). We plan to run a weekly seminar (one algorithm per week) presenting clear descriptions "in English" along with what little is carefully known.  David Aldous and Persi Diaconis  **************************************************  First Talk:  Thursday, October 5, 2000 Time:  3:15-4:15 Where:  Sequoia Hall, Room 200  Speaker:  Persi Diaconis  Title:  What Do We Know About the Metropolis Algorithm?  Abstract:    The metropolis algorithm is one of the most important tools of scientific computing!  I will give examples from cryptography and chemistry, a motivated derivation (joint work with Lou Billera) and a look at what is known about rates of convergence. Post-Doctoral Research Associate Position in Vaccine Design                           New Message   Reply   About this list   Date view   Thread view   Subject view   Author view           From:   rwoods_at_ccrc.uga.edu   Date:  2000-12-19 16:20:34        Next message:   gerard_at_xray.bmc.uu.se: "Uppsala Software News @ 2000-12-22 (Last issue of the second millennium !)"   Previous message:   michael.seewald_at_mpi-dortmund.mpg.de: "Re: geforce2GTS/linux"           Date: Tue, 19 Dec 2000 16:20:34 -0500 From: Robert J. Woods  rwoods_at_ccrc.uga.edu  Subject: [o-info] Post-Doctoral Research Associate Position in Vaccine Design       The Complex Carbohydrate Research Center ( http://www.ccrc.uga.edu ) is dedicated to the elucidation of the structure and function of carbohydrates in biology.  The structural techniques employed include X-ray crystallography, NMR spectroscopy and, macromolecular modeling.   As part of a multidisciplinary NIH-funded program, we are currently seeking a postdoctoral research associate to apply X-ray methods in the area of anti-bacterial and anti-fungal vaccine design. The structure of a carbohydrate-lectin complex relevant to xenotransplantation has just been refined in our laboratory.   We are particularly interested in the use of peptides as immunogen mimics of native carbohydrates, and the project will examine complexes in which carbohydrate ligand is replaced by peptides that have been shown to mimic the native ligand..    The responsibilities of the candidate will include all stages of crystallographic structure determination from crystallization to model refinement for the ligand-protein complexes.  Although the position may suit both individuals with experience in macromolecular crystallography and those with a desire to learn the technique, this position provides a great opportunity for someone able and willing to independently assume responsibility within this exciting area of research.    The postdoctoral associate will be under the direct supervision of experts in the fields of computational glycobiology (Dr. R. J. Woods,  http://glycam.ccrc.uga.edu ) and X-ray crystallography (Dr. B.-C. Wang,  http://www.uga.edu/~biocryst ), but will be encouraged to interact will other faculty through group meetings and seminars.    State of the art equipment for low-temperature data collection including rotating anode X-ray generators, image plate and CCD detectors and confocal X-ray optics are available on campus.  Computing facilities are superb and include SGI graphics workstations and our lab's own Origin 2000 supercomputer.  The individual will be expected to present their work at scientific meetings.  Travel funds are available for this purpose.     Depending on previous experience the salary range for this position is $28,000-$35,000.  The research associate is eligible for benefits according to University of Georgia policy. Please send a cover letter along with your currculum vitae and contact information for three referees to Dr. Woods at the address below.    *******************************************************************************************   Robert J. Home Page  |  Facilities  |  Reference  |  Software  |  Conferences  |  Announcements  |  Mailing Lists                  Neutron Scattering Announcement Archive            Neutron Scattering News Archive  |  Job Announcement Archive          Neutron Scattering News Archive    Thursday, August 9, 2001       Jane Brown has been awarded the 2001 Walter Hälg Prize of the European Neutron Scattering Association in recognition of her outstanding contributions to the science of neutron scattering over the last four decades. In making  the announcement , Prof. Cywinski wrote that "Professor Brown has made a significant impact upon our understanding of the fundamental magnetic properties of materials through her contributions to both the development and exploitation of polarised neutron diffraction and advanced spherical neutron polarimetry techniques for the precise determination of complex magnetic structures and spin density distributions." The presentation will be made at the  ICNS  in Munich.    Wednesday, April 25, 2001       Following the  ILL Millenium Symposium  on April 6-7, the ILL have posted the resulting the ILL Roadmap, and are requesting comments from the scientific community on the future directions the institute should explore. They have set up a  web forum  to solicit such input and are requesting comments to be submitted by May 14.     Thursday, April 5, 2001        Clifford G. Shull, who won the  1994 Nobel Prize in physics  "for pioneering contributions to the development of neutron scattering techniques for studies of condensed matter,"  has died at the age of 85 on March 31 . The Nobel prize, which he shared with Bertram Brockhouse, cited in particular his "development of the neutron diffraction technique." He started this work fifty years ago in collaboration with Ernest Wollan at what is now Oak Ridge National Laboratory. In 1955, he became a professor at MIT and was active in a series of pioneering studies using neutron scattering until his retirement in 1986. His family are setting up a scholarship fund in his honor at his alma mater, Carnegie Mellon University.     Thursday, February 1, 2001        The  European Neutron Scattering Association (ENSA)  has put out  a call for nominations  for the second ENSA Walter Hälg Prize for European Neutron Scattering, to be received by 12 June 2001. This is awarded biennially to a European scientist for outstanding, coherent work in neutron scattering with long-term impact on scientific and/or technical neutron scattering applications. The first such prize  was awarded in 1999 to Ferenc Mezei  for the invention of the spin-echo technique.     Monday, January 22, 2001        David Moncton has decided to  step down  as director of the  Spallation Neutron Source  project on March 1 to resume his work at Argonne full time. He was executive director of the $1.4 billion project for two years, but retained his responsibilities as Associate Laboratory Director at Argonne, which include running the  Advanced Photon Source .     Friday, January 19, 2001        Los Alamos have  announced  the new director of LANSCE. He is Paul Lisowski, a long-time Los Alamos scientist, who has been project director for both the National Accelerator Production of Tritium (APT) Project and the Laboratory's Advanced Hydrotest Facility.     Tuesday, December 26, 2000        Although the budget of the Japanese Diet will not be formally approved until next year,  Masa Arai has announced  that Phase 1 of the Joint Project between JAERI and KEK on high-intensity proton accelerators has been approved for construction.     Thursday, December 14, 2000        The US Department of Energy has posted the report of the BESAC subpanel on the review of spallation neutron facilities in the US. It strongly encourages growth in the funding of neutron scattering science within the US in preparation for the SNS, with recommendations to:          Immediately enhance activities at the IPNS facility       Restructure LANSCE/Lujan Center to deliver an internationally competitive user facility       Establish a program to expand the university base for neutron scattering.            The  Powerpoint presentations  by members of the panel can be downloaded from the Office of Science web site.     Tuesday, November 28, 2000        Since the previous news item concerning the death of Peter Verkerk, we have learned that Marta Alvarez Fernandez was also killed in the same accident. She was a guest at IRI from the Instituto Rocasolano in Madrid. The IRI has posted tributes to  Dr Verkerk  and  Dr Alvarez Fernandez  on their  web site . We would like to express our sympathy to all those affected by this tragedy.     Thursday, November 23, 2000        In a  message to the neutron scattering mailing list , Don Kearley announced the sad news of the death of Peter Verkerk in a motorcycle accident. He worked at IRI in Delft from 1971 and was a highly respected member of the international neutron scattering community for many years.     Wednesday, November 22, 2000        Los Alamos National Laboratory has just announced the resignation of Roger Pynn as Division Director of  LANSCE , effective from January 1, 2001.     Thursday, November 2, 2000        Bruce Brown has announced his decision to retire as Division Director of  IPNS  as soon as a  replacement has been appointed .     Wednesday, October 4, 2000         IPNS  and  KENS  have just signed an greement to promote collaborations in neutron scattering research, neutronics technology, cold-neutron instrumentation and data-analysis software. The agreement, which is for five years, establishes a Collaborative Research Program comprising the exchange of scientific and technical information and the exchange of research and technical staff.     Tuesday, October 3, 2000        The  Swedish  and  Danish  neutron scattering societies have joined forces in an  ESS-Scandinavia Initiative  supporting the construction of the  European Spallation Source  and promoting the Öresund region as a potential site.     Monday, October 2, 2000        It has just been announced that the Board of Governors of  Risø's National Laboratory , in Denmark, has decided to close down the research reactor DR3 permanently after forty years of operation. The reactor has not been operating since April 15 while an evaluation of its condition was carried out by the FORCE institute. That report has just been issued and the governing board concluded that the increased costs of maintenance do not justify further operation.         Risø has a long and distinguished history of neutron scattering. As the  official press release  says:      The shut down represents the end of an era in Danish research. A large number of foreign scientists have used the reactor's neutrons in experiments. DR3 has also provided the basis for the education of many Ph. D.-students and for a significant production of internationally acknowledged papers. The reactor has enjoyed a leading global position and has been frequently used as the only major research facility in Denmark seen in a European context.     Thursday, July 13, 2000        The contract for construction of Australia's Replacement Research Reactor was signed at ANSTO, just outside Sydney Australia. There is more information at  http://www.ansto.gov.au/info/cnrr000.html . K. Adya < a.k.adya@abertay.ac.uk >                  URL                           Application Deadline        July 31, 2003                  Description        As part of a major expansion in the university's environmental research programme following its RAE-2001 top rating in Scotland, a post-doctoral position is available to work in the growing area of non-destructive and functional quantification of biological processes by using Atomic Force Microscopy. The post would ideally suit a bio-physicist/bio-engineer with experience of scanning probe microscopy or related techniques and with a strong interest in working across boundaries. May 28, 2003        University of Edinburgh                  Job Title        Postdoctoral Research Associates in High Pressure Structural Physics                  Contact        Professor Richard Nelmes < r.j.nelmes@ed.ac.uk >                  URL        http://www.jobs.ed.ac.uk/                  Application Deadline        June 25, 2003                  Description        We invite applications for two or more postdoctoral research associates to join the High Pressure Structural Physics Group in the School of Physics at the University of Edinburgh, following the award of a £1.7M Programme Grant. We seek highly motivated individuals who can contribute to experimental research in one or more of the project areas funded by the Grant. The main areas are:                   Development of new techniques for high-pressure neutron diffraction with single-crystal, powder and liquid/amorphous samples, at the UK source ISIS in Oxfordshire             Neutron diffraction studies of ices (e.g. H 2 O, NH 3 , CH 4 ), gas hydrates, fundamental molecular systems (e.g. N 2 , O 2 , H 2 ), mixed molecular systems and iron-rich phases (e.g. FeS) under pressures up to 30GPa and above, mainly carried out at ISIS but possibly also at Saclay or the Institut Laue-Langevin in France.             Development of new techniques for high-pressure x-ray diffraction with single-crystal, powder and liquid/amorphous samples, at the UK synchrotron source SRS at Daresbury in Cheshire             X-ray diffraction studies of metallic elements (e.g. alkali and alkaline earth metals, lanthanides, Bi, Te), fundamental binary systems (e.g. GaAs, InSb, GaSb, CsI, NaBr) and novel materials (e.g. alkali metal/transition metal alloys) under pressures up to 100GPa and above, mainly carried out at SRS and on in-house x-ray facilities, but also at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility in France             Development and use of complementary techniques, such as optical spectroscopy, in the new Centre for Science at Extreme Conditions (CSEC) in Edinburgh                                                      May 7, 2003        Los Alamos Neutron Science Center                  Job Title        HIPPO Instrument Assistant, Technical Staff Member                  Contact        Sven Vogel < sven@lanl.gov >                  URL        http://www.hr.lanl.gov/                  Application Deadline        July 1, 2003                  Description        The Lujan Neutron Scattering Center at LANSCE is a high-power pulsed spallation neutron source with the mission to support a national user program in neutron scattering. We are seeking a highly motivated individual to work full time as part of a team investigating crystallographic changes in solids during various types of parametric studies (temperature, pressure, stress, chemistry etc.) using neutron diffraction. The successful candidate will assist with the operation of the "HIgh Pressure Preferred Orientation" spectrometer HIPPO at the Lujan Center. The responsibility of the successful candidate will include the day-to-day operation of the HIPPO instrumentation and its sample environments. This will include obtaining samples, assisting users with the set-up and operation of neutron experiments, as well as designing and developing software and hardware to assist with experiment automation, data processing, analysis and modeling. Other important duties are develop! ing and maintaining instrument and software documentation and acting as a subject matter expert regarding the HIPPO instrumentation. Some on-call work and travel may be required. Hurd, 505-665-0630 < ajhurd@lanl.gov >                  URL        http://www.hr.lanl.gov/                  Application Deadline        July 1, 2003                  Description        The Lujan Neutron Scattering Center at LANSCE is a high-power pulsed spallation neutron source with the mission to support a national user program in neutron scattering. We are seeking a highly motivated individual to work full time as a spallation neutron physicist. The successful candidate will be responsible for research into neutron production, transport, and flux in Lujan Center targets and instruments. The candidate will be expected to work closely with the Lujan Center's spallation physics team, including visitors, students and postdocs. User program services may include assisting users with energy spectra and time distribution questions about the neutron source, measurements of these quantities, and acting as a subject matter expert regarding all aspects of the spallation physics program. Other important duties include overseeing the development and maintenance of computational hardware, software, and documentation. On-call work and travel are required. PRINCIPAL SCIENTIST                   Blakely, E                         SCIENTISTS                   Chang, P     Char, D                         POSTDOCTORAL FELLOWS                   McNamara, M                         RESEARCH ASSOCIATES                   Bjornstad, K                         STUDENTS                   Nelson, J     Rosen, C     Simien, K                         GUESTS                       Deen, D     Feuerstein, B                STAFF                   Staff Names Coming Soon                                                                                        Basic fibroblast growth                        factor (designated FGF-2) is a cytokine that is involved                        in cell migration, proliferation and differentiation.                                  Its                        activities are not limited to just fibroblasts. FGF-2 is                        one member of a large family of homologous heparin-binding                        polypeptides. FGF-2 has also been shown to be an intracrine                        cytoplasmic-nuclear factor, whose expression is regulated                        by trans-synaptic and hormonal stimuli and which may act                        as a direct mediator of genomic responses to afferent stimulation.                        My laboratory is currently investigating a role for FGF-2                        in the radiation response of human lens epithelial cells                        and of human brain tumor cells. A novel aspect of our work                        is the culturing of the lens cells on an extracellular matrix                        derived from corneal endothelial cells. In collaboration                        with my colleague Dr. Mary Helen Barcellos-Hoff, we are                        also investigating the role of FGF-2 in the radiation response                        of the murine mammary gland and the lung.                         The large particle accelerators that were built for high-energy                          physics research at Berkeley Lab also provided unique                          radiations for the treatment of human cancer. The LBNL                          88-inch accelerator continues to be a source of radiation                          of variable ionization densities to study cellular and                          molecular mechanisms with our cell and tissue model systems.                          Our work investigating radiation-induced changes in FGF-2                          expression in several different tissues indicates that                          these changes are highly dependent on the radiation quality                          of the exposure. This conclusion has relevance for the                          currently expanding use of particle beams for cancer radiotherapy,                          and for the estimation of risk from occupational particle                          radiation exposures in space flight.                          Members of my laboratory working on various aspects of                          FGF-2 signal transduction include: Dr. Polly Y. Chang,                          Dr. Morgan P. McNamara and Ms. Kathleen Bjornstad.
